page.title: Native Americans in the United States

rev.comment: /* Native American mascots in sports */ no rationale for use
rev.diff:
Line 530: Line 530:
|accessdate = 2008-08-26
|accessdate = 2008-08-26
|author = Amy D'orio}}</ref> }}
|author = Amy D'orio}}</ref> }}
â   â
[[Image:Washington Redskins helmet rightface.png|155px|thumb|left|A Washington Redskins helmet with logo.]]
 
In August 2005, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) banned the use of "hostile and abusive" Native American mascots in postseason tournaments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/sports/july-dec05/mascots_8-25.html |work=Online NewsHour|title=NCAA Bans Indian Mascots |dateformat=mdy |accessdate=February 8 2006}}</ref> An exception was made to allow the use of tribal names as long as approved by that tribe (such as the [[Seminole Tribe of Florida]]'s approving use of their name for the team of [[Florida State University]].)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/08/24/sports/COLLEGE.php|title=Florida State wins its battle to remain the Seminoles|author=Powell, Robert Andrew|date=August 25, 2005|publisher=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=9 August|accessyear=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsu.com/pages/2005/06/17/historic_vote.html|title=Florida State University thanks Seminoles for historic vote of support|publisher=Florida State University|accessdate=9 August|accessyear=2008}}</ref> The use of Native American-themed team names in U.S. professional sports is widespread. Examples are mascot [[Chief Wahoo]] and teams such as the [[Cleveland Indians]] and [[Washington Redskins]], considered controversial by some.
In August 2005, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) banned the use of "hostile and abusive" Native American mascots in postseason tournaments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/bb/sports/july-dec05/mascots_8-25.html |work=Online NewsHour|title=NCAA Bans Indian Mascots |dateformat=mdy |accessdate=February 8 2006}}</ref> An exception was made to allow the use of tribal names as long as approved by that tribe (such as the [[Seminole Tribe of Florida]]'s approving use of their name for the team of [[Florida State University]].)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/08/24/sports/COLLEGE.php|title=Florida State wins its battle to remain the Seminoles|author=Powell, Robert Andrew|date=August 25, 2005|publisher=International Herald Tribune|accessdate=9 August|accessyear=2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsu.com/pages/2005/06/17/historic_vote.html|title=Florida State University thanks Seminoles for historic vote of support|publisher=Florida State University|accessdate=9 August|accessyear=2008}}</ref> The use of Native American-themed team names in U.S. professional sports is widespread. Examples are mascot [[Chief Wahoo]] and teams such as the [[Cleveland Indians]] and [[Washington Redskins]], considered controversial by some.
